comments.body: Shouldnâ€™t the `-f` be sufficient to not require a `chmod +w`?

I expected that too, but my testing says otherwise ðŸ¤· 

```
$ mkdir protected
$ touch protected/file
$ chmod -w protected
$ rm -f protected/file
rm: cannot remove 'protected/file': Permission denied
$ uname -a
Linux ubuntu-bionic 4.15.0-130-generic #134-Ubuntu SMP Tue Jan 5 20:46:26 UTC 2021 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
$ 
```
I admit Iâ€™m very confused now but I can reproduce so :shrug:

comments.body: Do these depend on the build having run? If not, could we move this to a separate job?

@garyverhaegen-da yeah it does depend on the build having run since we need the bazel build resolution and node modules and other build output to be interrogated to get the full list of libraries used
I'm not going to ask why `eq(variables['Agent.OS'], 'Linux')` alone is not sufficient.
That will still run it if the step before fails afaik.
Yes: the default implicit condition if you don't specify one is `succeeded()`, but if you do specify one it replaces that.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +23,27 @@  - bash: ./fmt.sh --test
    displayName: 'Platform-agnostic lints and checks'
    condition: and(succeeded(), eq(variables['Agent.OS'], 'Linux'))

  - bash: ci/configure-bazel.sh

comments.body: In the example at https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/process/conditions?view=azure-devops&tabs=yaml#use-a-template-parameter-as-part-of-a-condition the parameter is quoted. I guess that doesnâ€™t matter?

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +25,29 @@    # Temporary hack for 0.13.55. Should be removed once published.
    condition: and(succeeded(), eq(variables['Agent.OS'], 'Linux'),
                   ne(${{parameters.is_release}}, 'true'))

  - bash: ci/configure-bazel.sh

comments.body: What exactly are the implications on the user name here?

I know it looks like one, but this is not a username, this is the name of an Azure "connection service" to github. It has my name because I created it; it's not entirely clear to me how much it depends on my account and what happens the day my account disappears.

I could create another connection service in Azure with a more opaque name. However, despite having spent significant time looking into it, I have not found any way to create an Azure connection that is not linked to my account, so I figured we may as well have that explicitly in the name.

diffHunk:

    inputs:
      gitHubConnection: 'garyverhaegen-da'
      repositoryName: '$(Build.Repository.Name)'
      action: 'create'
